In chemical sciences, single crystal x-ray diffraction is the most versatile method for structure determination. For catalyst materials, the primary analytical application discussed in this tutorial review, powder x-ray diffraction is utilized by chemists, chemical engineers, geologists and materials scientists, where the ease and largely non-destructive nature of the polycrystalline sample preparation and data acquisition make this bulk characterization technique fast, simple, and informative. While it is difficult to determine the exact percentage of catalysis papers which utilize powder XRD as a key characterization technique, recent published issues of Applied Catalysis A have typically seen greater than 80 % of papers with a diffraction pattern either in the main work or the supplementary information [3]. Despite its importance and ubiquity, the information contained in powder XRD data for materials in catalysts is often neither fully harnessed nor correctly interpreted. We authors each have 15–20 years of experience at the interface of academic research and industrial application of x-ray diffraction used to characterize both catalyst active phases and the complex technical bodies used in full-scale commercial reactors. We were also excited to travel to Wurzburg to the site of Röntgen’s discovery ( Fig. 1). In this Tutorial Review, we aim to provide the wider catalysis community with a brief tutorial on some of the most encountered key aspects of powder XRD sample preparation, data collection, and instrumentation. We will emphasize characterization of broad classes of materials and the technical bodies relevant to large scale catalysis where various crystal sizes, shapes, dimensionalities and mixtures of materials are encountered. We hope that researchers across many fields, including those who are new to powder XRD or for whom XRD is not their primary technique, can become familiar with key diagnostics and be better equipped to interpret them in the context of their samples. More detailed and/or specialized information on powder X-ray diffraction instrumental set-ups and data analysis techniques can be found in several excellent reference resources. These include the International Tables for Crystallography maintained by the International Union of Crystallography [4], where in particular we point out Volume H on powder diffraction [5]. We also recommend multiple books containing a depth of information for those needing the next level of detail [6–8]. We start in Section 2 by describing the typical instrumental setups, x-ray sources, and different types of information commonly acquired from powder diffraction before proceeding to discuss particular applications and/or pitfalls for the various classes of catalyst materials in Section 3 (zeolites, metal oxides, MOFs, metals, metal sulfides, and the complex technical bodies typically comprising more than one type of material. The general background in Section 2 applies to each of the types of materials usually encountered in catalysis, while the material in Section 3 is specialized to the individual material type. 2 Methods and diffraction setup X-ray diffraction patterns from a powder sample show the intensity of diffracted X-rays as a function of the scattering angle. Each pattern of diffraction peak positions and intensities is therefore a unique fingerprint for a specific structure and composition. Peaks in the XRD pattern meet the Bragg condition and are related to interplanar spacings. All spacings in the structure need to be illuminated by the X-ray beam i.e. a sufficiently large number of crystallites with random orientation. As discussed later in this section, this is typically achieved by preparing and aligning a fine-grained powder sample in the X-ray beam and optionally spinning or oscillating the sample to achieve as much orientation averaging as possible. Information that can be obtained from a typical laboratory powder diffraction pattern includes the following in increasing order of complexity: phase identification of one or multiple phases, intensity of a phase, crystallite size, doping of elements into a structure, structure changes with temperature/process conditions, and structure solutions of newly synthesized materials. Pictorial representations of the extraction of the more basic analyses are shown in Fig. 2 and discussed throughout this section. Peaks in the diffraction pattern show up at positions which can be calculated from the Bragg Equation, shown in Equation 1. Equation 1: the Bragg Equation: n λ = 2 d sin θ In the Bragg equation, n is the order of reflection (and usually assumed to be 1), λ is the wavelength of the x-ray source, d is the spacing between the crystal planes, and θ is the angle between the x-ray source and the sample (see TOC graphic for a visual depiction). While 2nd or 3rd order reflection can occur (n = 2, 3) as scattered x-rays come back into phase, constructive interference is strongest for first order, and n is typically 1 for peaks observed in common experiments [9]. While much information is available by proper analysis of the x-ray diffraction pattern as we will describe further in detail, it is also important to understand what information XRD cannot provide in catalysis science. Many catalysts comprise amorphous phases or mixtures of crystalline and amorphous phases. XRD does not provide information about amorphous materials or amorphous regions of otherwise crystalline materials. In particular, quantification of the relative intensity of a crystalline phase can be difficult should significant amorphous material appear in the sample. This is particularly problematic when the elemental composition of the amorphous phase differs significantly from the crystalline phase(s) of interest meaning additional mass absorption factors should be considered. Moreover, XRD is a bulk technique. That is, it provides analysis of the crystalline bulk phase(s) in the sample. Because catalysis is a local phenomenon, one needs to be careful about drawing conclusions regarding the structure of a catalytically active surface because the active site may not be the dominant phase present in a sample or may be a defect site in a crystalline phase. 2.1 Important points regarding, and a basic introduction to the diffractometer Diffractometers collect data by scanning across an angular range and are typically set up in Bragg-Brentano (BB) configuration with either θ-θ or θ-2θ reflection geometries ( Fig. 3). This can also be referred to as divergent beam geometry. Of the 30 papers identified during our survey of papers in recent ApplCatal A issues, 28 of 30 used these geometries, with only 2 using a transmission geometry.3 In θ-θ, the X-ray source and the detector both move symmetrically, while in θ-2θ the source is fixed and the sample tilts (θ) and the detector moves (2θ). In instruments using θ-2θ geometries, because the sample moves off horizontal, be especially careful to pack samples such that they do not spill into the instrument. High-speed Bragg-Brentano (BB) configuration (Fig. 3B) is the most appropriate configuration for routine use in the study of catalysts as it has a number of practical advantages over both traditional BB using a point detector (Fig. 3A) and high-speed transmission experiments (Fig. 3C and 3D). First, high-speed data collection maximizes data quality (both angular resolution and signal/noise) for a given allocation of instrument time. Secondly, consistent sample volume using a surface aligned powder sample is optimal for a wide variety of XRD analysis routines from phase identification to quantitative analysis of the crystalline phases in a mixture (Rietveld refinement) and Relative Intensity phase analysis (I/Ic) as discussed later in Section 2. However, there are also some disadvantages to this configuration. The detector array can be accessible to a range of 2θ positions of approximately 5º 2θ from the desired angle 2θ. Therefore, scattered X-rays may be problematic, particularly at low 2θ angles where the detector is close to or overlapping with the divergent direct beam. With BB geometry and high-speed detector configurations it is recommended to position an anti-scatter slit, commonly known as a ‘knife edge’, perpendicular to the plane of the sample above the midpoint to reduce the high background scatter which can be otherwise observed up to 40º 2θ. The downside to a fixed knife edge is that at higher 2θ angles (typically >80°), all or some of the X-ray beam may be blocked. Some vendors now offer motorized knife edge assemblies to automate the repositioning for different experiments. Transmission experiments (Fig. 3D) have some key advantages over BB particularly for specialist XRD investigations. In contrast to the precise geometries required for the BB experiment, the transmission beam configuration is more tolerant of small changes in the sample position (sample displacement) from the ideal zero-point. This means that parallel beam (Fig. 3C) is recommended for in-situ experiments such as variable temperature studies where there is a possibility for drying or related outgassing to lead to movement/texture on the powder surface. Another benefit is that the X-ray beam illuminates the same portion of sample throughout each experiment whereas with BB the beam footprint changes ( Fig. 4). Quantitative analysis of small sample sizes are also feasible via this geometry if enough signal intensity can be collected in your instrument. Glass or quartz sealed capillaries of powder sample are often the preferred choice for transmission experiments and can be used to apply specific environmental condition on the sample. For example, vacuum or controlled gas atmosphere can be used and the sample readily heated and cooled using a cryostream or hot air blower on the capillary outer surface. State-of-the-art powder diffraction beamlines at synchrotron facilities use a transmission geometry and capillary sample stage together with high precision multi-crystal analyzers to produce extremely high-resolution powder diffraction data. While XRD is typically a non-destructive technique for inorganic materials, it is still an ionizing radiation. Therefore, exposure to long durations of high-intensity X-ray radiation can lead to damage of the more sensitive organic species. This is of course more prevalent at the synchrotron where the intensity is orders of magnitude greater than that of a typical laboratory source. See Section 3.2.3 for a discussion of this phenomenon for MOFs, a particularly sensitive class of materials. The X-ray wavelength (λ) used for data collection depends on the type of X-rays used ( Table 1) [10]. While some instruments are set up with multiple tubes, typically only one source is available. Copper is the workhorse, most frequently used source and has a value of 1.5406 Å [11]. Unless otherwise noted in this paper, values stated in degrees 2θ are assuming copper as the XRD source. In our survey, 27 of 30 papers used copper, 2 used cobalt, and 1 was performed at a synchrotron [3]. Other elemental sources are used to avoid sample fluorescence or to compress or expand observed peaks into 2θ ranges more readily observable for that material type. 2.1.1 Sample holders Your catalyst material will be packed into a sample holder which may be constructed of plastic, aluminum, or another metal. Sample holders for each diffractometer differ, but squares and circles are the most common shapes. The material of construction should be considered due to the appearance of peaks corresponding to the holder if the x-ray beam penetrates the sample or the beam is off the sample on the edge of the holder. Choice of sample holder material becomes very important for data acquired at low angle. Because the x-ray beam is spread out at low angle as shown in Fig. 4, it is likely that the sample holder could be “visible”. Many plastics have diffraction peaks in this region. If there is a low angle peak which is always present in the x-ray pattern, it could be the sample holder material or interference from the XRD sample stage. This concept can easily be tested by scanning an empty holder. When choosing a peak for intensity measurements, ensure that the beam is completely on the packed sample when the peak is collected. If the x-ray beam is spilling off the sample when a peak is collected, very slight differences in sample pack height will result in significant variation in intensity values. The beam dimensions on the sample surface at any 2θ can be calculated if you know the beam length and optic sizes for your x-ray diffractometer. Alternatively, a fluorescent holder can allow for a visual determination of the size and shape of the beam at any 2θ value. The fluorescent screen is also a very good tool for instrument optics troubleshooting because the overall shape and location of the beam can be seen ( Figs. 4 & 5). 2.1.2 Low angle analysis Low angle peaks (less than ∼10º 2θ) in the XRD pattern are highly sensitive to instrument, environment, and materials parameters. These peaks describe larger features in the crystalline structure (>9 Å, copper radiation). The intensity and angular positions of these peaks can vary with the absorption of water or hydrocarbons. Low angle features are also highly affected by packing as well as the holder or diffractometer stage. Slight inconsistencies in the surface of the packed powder can result in anomalous features in the XRD pattern. When scanning below 5º 2θ, ensure that nothing blocks the path of the X-rays. Often care must be taken with the instrument stage or sample holder to prevent this type of pattern anomaly (Fig. 5). Breadth of the beam is particularly important at these low angles as the beam divergence creates a large footprint on the sample. This can be addressed by using a smaller divergence slit on the x-ray source side (Fig. 3E), although there is a tradeoff: smaller slits mean less intensity. In addition, axial-divergence error is also significant at these low angles, that is the divergence due to the beam being a line focus rather than a single point and is in plane with the sample, typically referred to as the axial direction in the diffractometer (axial direction in Fig. 3E is parallel to the knife edge). Axial-divergence error presents as asymmetry on the leading edge of the diffraction peaks (towards lower 2θ) and can be partially mitigated by Soller slits [6]. A cartoon representation of the impact of Soller slits is shown in Fig. 3E where the incident beam on the left from the source can diverge in the axial direction (up and down page) but after passing through a Soller slit, i.e. a series of foils of equal length and equal spacing, the beam is effectively collimated into individual paths. As this axial-divergence is also possible on the diffracted beam, it is typical to have a Soller slit on the receiving optics as well to reduce the axial-divergence further. As the Soller slits are situated in the beam, there is some attenuation of the beam intensity and therefore a trade-off between intensity and removing the axial-divergence, a Soller slit which subtends an angle of + /-2.5° will remove much of the axial-divergence error with acceptable attenuation of the beam intensity [6]. In our laboratory, we are often looking at low angle peaks, therefore we usually utilize the largest divergence slit that allows the beam to completely stay on the sample and utilize a count time per step that gives good counting statistics for peaks of interest. If desired, alternative geometry setups like Debye-Scherrer (transmission, Fig. 3D) performed on samples loaded into capillaries would also address this issue. Not shown in Figs. 4 and 5 is the knife edge we use to help reduce high backgrounds from anomalous air scatter. We recommend the use of a knife edge if acquiring data at less than 40º 2θ. 2.2 Sample preparation Samples for powder diffraction should be a fine powder < 100mesh. This can be accomplished with mortar and pestle or by mechanical milling. Take care as over milling can result in damage or change to the sample and unit cell in some materials. For example, sample crystallinity may be decreased (e.g. in zeolites) [12,13] or crystal polymorph may change (e.g. CaCO3) [14,15]. Therefore, only mill as long as necessary to achieve desired particle size while avoiding heat generation in the process. If the sample contains mainly light elements such as organics, attention should be paid to sample thickness. If the packed sample is not thick enough it is possible for the X-rays to travel through the packed sample and additionally diffract off the sample holder. We see this most frequently during in-situ experiments where temperature is a controlled factor and the sample holder often contributes to the total XRD pattern. If this is suspected, a pattern of an empty sample holder can be compared with the sample pattern for confirmation. The surface of the packed sample should also be smooth and continuous with the sample level to the edges of the sample holder to reduce pattern peak shift. Fig. 6 and S1 show why samples should be smooth; cracks, lumps and other sample preparation defects can result in spurious peaks and other odd features, particularly at low angle, which prevent phase identification or mislead intensity measurements. Samples packed too high or too low will suffer from zero offset alignment issues and all peaks will be shifted to higher or lower 2-theta respectively. The amount of pattern shift is determined by the height of the overpack and/or underpack (greater height difference = greater shift) and the diffractometer geometry with the length of the goniometer arms a key parameter (shorter arms = less shift). Packing fine powders can best be accomplished with a glass microscope slide or similar thin metal tool. Plastic can result in static generation which is undesirable with fine powders. For best results, ensure that the surface of the packing implement is wider than the holder well. Fine powder should be sprinkled into sample well and then pressed firmly down. If there are gaps in the surface, additional material may be added and pressed into the gaps. Twisting and sliding motions can result in preferred orientation in materials with very large crystals > 5um or in materials with plate and needle like morphologies. Preferred orientation occurs due to non-random orientation of the crystal faces and results in an atypical XRD pattern for the material which can hinder Phase ID and Relative Intensity measurements ( Fig. 7 and Figure S2). When a sample is subject to preferred orientation, slight differences in packing technique can greatly affect the XRD pattern. For known materials, the presence and nature of preferred orientation can be realized by comparing peak heights for hkl index phases against a known powder diffraction file, typically called a PDF card. These diffraction files are compiled in databases of known phases available in XRD software. Specialty sample holders can be obtained which allow for side packing or back fill packing. These types of specialty packing techniques can reduce or eliminate preferred orientation effects in a sample. Most catalyst materials such as zeolites and metal oxides are small enough to randomly orient in packed samples and do not require these additional packing considerations. 2.3 Typical information that can by obtained by powder XRD 2.3.1 Phase identification Identification of crystalline phases, or Phase ID in short, is the most basic but powerful aspect of XRD. A crystalline material, if prepared and packed properly, should always give the same set of diffraction peak positions and intensities by XRD. Both the relative intensity of peaks within a pattern and the peak position (d‐space or angular 2θ, see Fig. 2A) will be the same unless there is preferred orientation or adsorbate (CO2/water/hydrocarbon/solvent) effects. Powder Diffraction Files (PDF) exist for most known materials and can be visually or digitally matched to experimental patterns to determine the crystalline phase(s) present in the experimental sample. In more complex mixtures, it may be helpful to incorporate profile analysis to better resolve diffraction peaks for individual phases. As discussed later in Section 2.3.3, a crystalline phase with isotropic crystallite size broadening would have consistent peak broadening across the diffraction pattern and grouping peaks by similar FWHM (see Fig. 2C) can help refine the list of unidentified peaks for database searches. However, anisotropic broadening effects are also possible within a single phase diffraction pattern so this approach is not always successful. Many PDF databases exist, some general, some specific to material types [16–19]. Some are free to utilize while others require a paid license. These databases can be imported (or were previously imported by the manufacturer) into XRD software that can perform search match functions [20–23]. Each software program has a different set of operations/button clicks required to search the current pattern against the PDF database(s), so we do not cover this here. While instrumental software often does an adequate job, we do prefer the XRD software JADE [23]. X-ray diffraction is a technique where the linear combination of all diffraction peaks contributes to the observed pattern. Therefore, if additional peaks in the XRD pattern under investigation are not fit by the main PDF pattern, there are likely additional crystalline phase(s) in the sample. The same can be true if relative intensities of peaks in the main phase aren’t quite correct; please see Section 3.6 for a more complete discussion. We also sometimes utilize pattern indexing (see Section 2.4.1) to determine if all peaks in a pattern belong to the same space group and hence may be a single phase or if additional peaks are present which are not possible in the expected space group. If these “contaminant phase(s)” are very minor there may only be a single peak (the most intense peak in the contaminant PDF pattern) available for phase ID. Typically, an educated guess can be made when attempting to identify a low level contaminate phase if a good PDF database is available and the primary diffracting phase, sample origin, and synthetic chemistry approach are well understood. 2.3.2 Intensity measurements Intensity is the determination of extent of crystallinity of a phase by XRD (see Fig. 2B and 2D). Initially, a Phase ID should be performed to determine if all peaks present in the pattern are due to the main phase. It is important to know if there are multiple phases so that the proper peaks can be chosen for intensity integration. Secondary phases should be noticed for interpretation of additional catalytic data and must be accounted for if performing Whole Pattern Fitting [24,25] or Rietveld analysis [26]. Rietveld refinement, first described by Hugo Rietveld in the 1960s is a least-squares refinement approach to fit a simulated diffraction pattern to experimental data [26]. This powerful technique can be used to model all structural and instrument parameters to match the experimental data and is the most common approach for powder X-ray diffraction refinement in use. A major challenge of the Rietveld method is that a sufficiently good approximation of the crystal structure is required before the fine structure and morphology properties can be refined. In addition, a complete description of the instrument parameters is also necessary to correct the peak shape contributions from the X-ray diffractometer. As with many advanced data analysis and refinement techniques, the quality of the inputs directly influences the quality of the outputs and a reasonable background knowledge of the basics of crystallography and the diffractometer is recommended before attempting Rietveld refinement [27]. If only one phase is present and background of the pattern is flat (amorphous materials tend to result in broad raised backgrounds) generally, a sample can be considered mostly crystalline in the main phase. Note that even when the background is very flat visually, there can be as much as 10 % amorphous material in the sample. Intensity measurements are particularly good for comparison purposes, therefore, reporting intensity relative to a standard (i.e. Relative Intensity or I/Ic) is a common practice rather than reporting absolute intensity due to the possible presence of amorphous material. The reference material used to quantitate Relative Intensity must be chosen for each type of material. Some typical uses for Relative Intensity measurements are evaluation of repeat material syntheses, determination of the amount of active component (i.e. zeolite/MOF) in a multi-component catalyst formulation, or determination of the extent of crystallinity loss after testing or an intermediate process such as steaming. Preferred orientation, when the crystal faces being measured are not completely random in the experimentally packed sample due to bulk crystal features such as plates or needles, is a major problem for intensity determination (Fig. 7). When preferred orientation is present, intensity can sometimes be estimated with Whole Pattern Fitting or Rietveld analysis which take into account crystal sizes but never when integrating the areas under a peak (peak integration method). It is best to work to experimentally eliminate the preferred orientation with specialized packing techniques prior to attempting an intensity analysis. Two basic routes for intensity determination are used: 1) Whole Pattern Fitting or Rietveld Analysis and 2) Peak Integration [28]. In either case, ensure that the same scan parameters (scan rate, step size, slit sizes, etc.) are run on all comparative samples and that they are prepared and run under similar environmental conditions because temperature and/or level of hydration can affect intensity. If there are low level contaminants in any of the samples being compared that are not well described by the Whole Pattern Fitting or Rietveld Analysis, Peak Integration (see Fig. 2D) is the preferred method. A newer method used for quantitation is the Direct Derivation (aka Toraya) method which uses the sums of intensities for individual components. Here, accurate chemical composition data (phase and elemental) is required [29]. The determination of the best peaks to measure for Peak Integration / Relative Intensity method is not necessarily straight forward and must be determined for each catalyst material. Rules of thumb include: Low angle peaks (below ∼5–10º 2θ) are not optimal due to absorption and instrumental effects. Choose peaks above the 2θ where the X-Ray beam is completely on the packed surface. Choose peaks that are not affected by humidity or potential contaminant phases. Finally, if possible, choose 3–5 larger peaks for good counting statistics. The rationale for peak selection should be explained in publications, at least in the Supplemental Information. Both peak height (Fig. 2B) and peak area (Fig. 2D) are related to crystallinity, but peak height varies with crystallite size, therefore, peak area is the best measurement for Relative Intensity determination. To determine Relative Intensity (see Equation 2) run the reference sample and the comparative sample, then perform Whole Pattern Fitting/Rietveld Analysis or Peak Integrations on the same peaks in each pattern. With the intensity values obtained perform the simple calculation below. It is important to run the reference in the same time frame as the sample because X-Ray tubes decrease in intensity over time. Best practice is to run an intensity standard daily, but for academic shared instruments, running the sample of interest and reference sample back-to-back is sufficient. Finally, ensure that your reference sample and comparative sample have similar Mass Adsorption Coefficients (MAC) using an elemental analysis technique. MAC refers to the ability of an element to absorb X-Rays [30]. If the chemical composition of the reference and sample are very similar, MAC will not be a problem. But if they are different, a correction may need to be applied. Variation between samples in content of very heavy elements such as Zr, high x-ray absorbers like potassium (K) or very light elements such as carbon (C) can result in incorrect assumptions when reporting Relative Intensity. Equation 2: Relative Intensity = (Intensity of Comparative Sample/Intensity of Reference Sample) *100 2.3.3 Crystallite size, strain and the Scherrer equation The width of peaks in the XRD pattern can also yield significant information about the microstructure of a material. The observed broadening can have contributions from crystallite size, crystal strain and potentially other forms of crystalline defects, however it can often be simplified and attributed simply to an average crystallite size effect. As the crystallite size of a material decreases from large visible crystals to nanoscale dimensions, XRD peaks broaden. The Scherrer equation, shown in Equation 3, quantitatively describes the broadening of a peak at a particular diffraction angle (θ), as it relates the crystalline domain size (L, typically specified in Å for dimensional consistency with the x-ray wavelength) to the FWHM, i.e. width of the peak at half of its height (β, in º2θ but needs to be converted to radians for dimensional consistency and cancellation), see Fig. 2C for a graphical explanation. The x-ray wavelength λ (in Å, see Table 1) also factors. The value β is defined as B-b where the measured broadening is B and the instrumental broadening is b. Please note, each instrument and configuration has a different lower limit of sample broadening that may be detected above the instrument broadening limit. Crystallite size analysis benefits from higher angular resolution data and optimizing the scan conditions may be necessary to measure larger crystallite size materials. Various options may be available to improve this angular resolution from narrowing the divergence slits to adding an incident beam monochromator. Check with instrument operating manual for the optimal conditions. To correct for the instrument broadening (b) in the analysis, instrument broadening correction curves are usually measured by running a scan of a highly crystalline NIST reference material like LaB6 [31] under the same analysis condition as the sample. This allows for the sample broadening (β) to be calculated by subtracting the expected instrument broadening (FWHM) from the total measured peak FWHM at a given d‐spacing. Figure S3 gives a longer explanation of key points surrounding determination of FWHM, including showing that at least 7 points should be present in the diffraction pattern above the half-max line. The Scherrer constant K is typically taken to be unity, i.e. 1 [32]. Scherrer Equation 3: L =(K λ) / (β cos θ) Each peak of the examined pattern can be evaluated independently and with any luck should produce a consistent crystalline domain size. Scientists should put special emphasis on the proper selection of hkl reflections for analysis for estimation of crystallite size, especially when crystals are anisotropic or the crystal structure is far from cubic. For analysis of FAU zeolite, a cubic structure, we are usually reporting the average of 5 peaks between 25 and 45º 2θ. For monoclinic or lower symmetry materials, independent estimates should be made for each crystal dimension (100, 001, etc) if feasible. Further, it is important to remember crystalline domain size does not necessarily correspond to particle size, as particles observed by TEM or SEM can be polycrystalline, containing multiple crystalline domains. In some cases it may be necessary to deconvolute the impacts of size and strain broadening on a crystalline material. For many materials, stress/strain contributions are negligible to the observed peak width, but for certain materials, like 1-dimensional zeolites with long crystal lengths in one-dimension, the effect can be significant [33]. There are also examples in catalysis where the microstrain is linked to performance such as the strain as measured on a Cu(111) reflection correlated to the turnover frequency for methanol synthesis [34]. Where it is necessary to move beyond the Scherrer equation [35], a common next step is to use the Williamson-Hall method to deconvolute size and strain [36]. This approach utilizes the fact that crystallite size (D) has a 1/cosθ dependence whereas the strain component (ε) possesses as tanθ dependance. Williamson-Hall Equation 4: βhkl cosθ = (Kλ)/D + 4ε(sinθ) This means a plot of βcosθ vs 4sinθ should be a straight line where the strain component can be obtained from the slope and the size component from the intercept. Since the original work, there are also some modified models using the Williamson-Hall approach which may better suit certain systems. More information and a mathematical theory on the Williamson-Hall approach is discussed by Mote et al. [37] 2.3.4 Solid-solutions / elemental doping Chemically, a solid solution occurs when one element can isomorphously substitute for another in the same crystal structure. Classical examples include the Y2O3 / ZrO2 / HfO2 / CeO2 oxide systems, the substitution of Si by Al in zeolites, and many perovskite systems. In XRD patterns of solid solutions, the peak positions can be used to determine the amount of substitution into the base structure as long as other variables are constant. As the unit cell for a given structure expands (or contracts), peak positions move due to the change in distance between planes in the unit cell. This shift in peak position is often referred to as lattice parameter. While Rietveld analysis can be used to determine the unit cell of a material, for materials with known structures, it is also possible to index the pattern and calculate unit cell constants from the exact 2θ position of select peaks with known hkl values. Knowing the unit cell parameters and the crystal system the d‐spacing expected for each hkl reflection can be calculated. For example, as shown in Fig. 8, the crystal structure for copper metal is face-centered cubic with a unit cell parameter (for cubic: a = b= c) of 3.615 Å [38]. For a cubic system, the d‐spacing for each reflection (hkl) can be calculated from equation 5. Equation 5: 1/d2 = (h2 + k2 + l2)/a2 Solving for the Cu (111) reflection: 1/d2 = (1 +1 +1)/3.6152 = 0.22956 → d = √(1/0.22956) = 2.087 Å Finally, the Bragg Equation (Equation 1) can be used to convert the d‐spacing to expected 2θ positions for Cu kα radiation (43.31°). These theoretical peak position values can be tabulated for all hkl reflections and related back to the measured diffraction pattern to assign an hkl label to each measured reflection. Subsequently, one can use these hkl values to calculate the experimental unit cell size value using the experimentally measured peak positions. From the experimentally derived pattern, one must also correct or refine the peak position for sample displacement errors. The preferred method for this is to dope a sample with a peak position standard such as NIST Silicon 646 or LaB6 possessing a certified unit cell dimension [31]. Specific examples are shown for the individual material types discussed in Section 3. This unit cell analysis approach can then be used to evaluate the lattice shift observed for solid-solution alloys where the experimenatal peaks can shift based on the composition such as the bimetallic Cu/Ni system [39]. Helpfully, in the modern day, this process is seldom done manually. Software can quickly automate the process and most XRD analysis software provides the option to simulate peak positions for a given unit cell and crystal system. Some, including popular freeware options such as GSAS II [20] or FULLPROF [22] also allow the user to simulate the full XRD pattern given a known crystal structure file (.cif) from a literature source as the input. 2.3.5 Structural changes As the structure of heterogeneous catalysts is often key to their catalytic performance, monitoring for changes to or from that desired structure is essential to maintaining an active catalyst. Many preparations, treatments and procedures on crystalline materials from thermal treatment of catalyst or binder, ion or solvent exchange, oxidation or reduction treatments for metals and oxides, etc may lead to structure changes. Where measurable changes are observed, XRD is an invaluable tool used to monitor, and in some cases, quantify these changes using the Relative Intensity or Rietveld methods discussed earlier. XRD analysis is commonly used in all stages of the catalyst development from synthesis through scale up and development to monitoring in active operations ensuring that the correct structural forms are present and stable. In zeolite chemistry for example, additional catalyst scaleup, development and robustness work may be required to supplement learnings from the exploratory synthesis of the prototype to ensure that the desired catalyst can be produced at scale and that failure modes can be mitigated. As metastable aluminosilicate polymorphs, zeolites can be chemically very similar yet structurally very distinct, to the point where the same synthesis gel can form intermediate phases (kinetic products) which transition into other more thermodynamically favorable zeolitic phases with additional synthesis time at temperature [40,41]. Structural changes can take many forms [42], and it is important to note any changes in the observed pattern from the expected result. For more flexible porous materials such as MOFs and related materials, it is possible that reversible changes such as solvation and drying procedures result in major bulk changes observed in the diffraction pattern [43,44]. Despite these major structural distortions or rearrangement these processes may still be reversible and quantifiable using XRD analysis. More subtle peak intensity and profile shape changes could be equally important to understanding the catalyst or adsorbent behavior. As one example, select single peaks split into two or more peaks indicating a more gradual change of crystal symmetry which may be measured and plotted as a series over time or temperature ( Fig. 9) [45]. When troubleshooting, it can be advantageous to compare spent or deactivated catalysts directly with retains of that same lot in the activated form prior to testing as any subtle changes may be confused with lot-to-lot variation in the preparation. Post-synthesis, it is common for most porous materials to undergo some form of heat-treatment or ‘activation’ step prior to catalytic testing. The purpose can vary from removing water or other solvent molecules from the pore system to more severe thermal treatments designed to decompose organics species such as structure directing agents or ammonium ions [46]. These activation procedures may be associated with a measurable change in the bulk structure of the porous material enabling XRD analysis to evaluate if a procedure was successful. Care must be taken to optimize these heat treatment conditions as excessive heating can often lead to unwanted structural changes. Variable-temperature XRD is a useful technique to understand the thermal stability of a material under controlled conditions and can be performed in-situ using a programmable stage. Most XRD instrument vendors either offer their own custom-made stage for this purpose or partner with a 3rd party to make the capability available. However, if a suitable instrument is not available, is it also possible to perform a similar experiment ex-situ using a series of samples treated at different temperatures, cooled and analyzed as a typical powder sample. Be careful using these ex-situ processes if the thermally treated material is unstable in ambient air or if it undergoes reversible changes with temperature. 2.4 Solving unknown crystal structures While single crystal x-ray diffraction is the dominant method used for structure solution and has been complemented recently by electron crystallography methods (referred to as rotation electron diffraction RED or MicroED) [47], it is also possible to solve new material structures from powder XRD data and there remain cases where the only available diffraction data with which to solve the structure is on powder samples. If the material of study is amenable to forming single-crystals, it is typically preferable to pursue single-crystal diffraction method to solve the structure. The complicating factor for structure solution from powder data is a lack of phase amplitude (i.e. an incomplete reciprocal space map) for a given diffraction peak. Historically, all the initial zeolite phases, and most binary and ternary oxide phases including the perovskites have been solved from powder XRD data [48,49]. Structure solution from powder XRD data is beyond the scope of this tutorial review, hence we do not go into detail other than to mention certain aspects of structure solution that may come into play for other analyses. For structure solution work, it is critically important that the data quality is as high as possible and that additional analytical methods (repeat syntheses, electron and optical microscopy, etc.) have been used to show the material is a single phase. As XRD data is inherently low dimensionality data, the peak positions, intensities, and angular resolution should be optimized as well to isolate as many of the overlapping peaks as possible. Therefore, synchrotron XRD data is the preferred option for structure solution work as the dedicated national laboratory facilities which operate the powder diffraction beamlines utilize the best technology available while continuously calibrating and optimizing the diffractometers to ensure that data quality is the best available. With the development of mail-in programs, synchrotron sources are becoming more widely accessible. As multi-user facilities, time and sometimes financial considerations (proprietary time for industry) occur as these facilities are utilized by researchers all across the world. However, angular resolution of a diffraction peak is a function of both the instrument broadening and the sample broadening (crystallite size/strain). For materials with a high crystallinity, larger domains of coherent periodic repeat units, synchrotron resolution is typically preferred for both the angular resolution, consistency of peak intensities and the signal/noise resolution. That said, for synthetic materials which may only form as nano-crystalline agglomerates, there may not be much of a practical difference between a monochromatic Cu Kα1 laboratory instrument and a synchrotron source if the data collection is sufficiently long on the laboratory system to achieve similar counting statistics as we recently showed in solving the structure of the very complicated zeolite UZM-55 from laboratory powder XRD data in combination with physical and electronic model building [50,51]. 2.4.1 Pattern indexing In structure solution, for suspected pure single phase materials, an early step should be to attempt to index the unit cell and assign hkl values to the observed diffraction peaks enabling the unit cell parameters to be determined. Essentially, from the observed peaks, one can mathematically determine potential space groups for a diffraction pattern. The mathematical background to this approach can be found in textbooks such as Elements of X-ray Diffraction [7], however in practical terms XRD analysis software typically provides some integrated powder indexing algorithms to assist with this step. For software indexing, the first step is to identify peak positions for all the strong reflections of a crystalline phase. For patterns with well resolved peaks this can simply be a list of the observed 2θ position and relative intensity vs the strongest observed reflection for all the visible peak maxima. In cases where there is a high degree of peak overlap, it may be necessary to profile fit the individual peaks to better resolve and list the observed peak positions. Ideally at least 20 strong lines are observed and passed to the indexing programs. This list is then used to search the theoretical peak positions and intensities of the various crystal systems and unit cell dimensions to find the best match. There are a variety of indexing software and algorithmic tools to assist with this stage of the process; some of the more common examples are the DICVOL and TREOR algorithms [52–54] which search starting from higher (cubic) symmetry down until a suitable figure of merit match is found. The many different software packages have slight variations on implementation of search algorithms and the associated parameter options and therefore it can be advantageous to utilize more than one tool or approach to add confidence to the result. In an ideal scenario, the strong, easily distinguished ∼20 peaks are sufficient for the algorithm to conclusively identify the unit cell. With very large cell and lower symmetry materials, it can be challenging to both deconvolute the observed peaks due to the extensive overlap and get a unique fit based on the observed figure of merit. In these cases, it may be beneficial to verify that the search parameters used by the software are not limiting the search and allow for large cell parameter to be identified. It may be necessary to increase any default search limits. Following identification of the crystal system and unit cell dimensions, the next step is to identify the space group. In simple terms, symmetry operations performed on the atomic positions within a unit cell relate those atoms in one part of the unit cell to another. This can be such that the scattering of one group is exactly cancelled by another and therefore a class of reflections has exactly zero intensity. These are referred to as systematic absences and can help narrow down the list of space groups which suitably represent a diffraction pattern. The International Tables for Crystallography [55] provide a detailed description and tables for the allowed reflection conditions for each crystal system. In practice, it can be a lengthy trial and error process to identify a list of plausible options for further investigation. This is particularly true for porous catalytic systems with relatively large unit cells. A more typical outcome of the indexing process is a list of plausible cell options all with reasonable figure-of-merit fits to the original reflection list. For example, one may see a cubic cell and then a tetragonal distortion thereof or an orthorhombic cell and the related monoclinic cell. It is then necessary to validate these results against the observed XRD pattern utilizing a more detailed fitting approach often referred to as whole pattern fitting. While still structure-less at this stage, Le Bail and Pawley fitting methods can be used to model a full XRD pattern using the unit cell and space-group settings identified from the initial indexing to now validate these proposed cells against the full pattern not just to top 20 selected peaks [25,56]. This technique can also be useful for determining whether a pattern is expected to be phase pure, particularly when performing exploratory synthesis where expected materials may be unknown. If the indexing returned by analysis software shows lower than monoclinic symmetry, the best guess is likely to be that multiple phases are present in the observed pattern. Detailed XRD analysis which progresses from pattern indexing into structure solution efforts requires a comprehensive knowledge of crystallography beyond the scope of this article and the authors recommend further reading to familiarize with the topic before proceeding. Some useful resources are an Introduction to Crystallography by Sands [8] and Crystal Structure Analysis: Principles and Practice by Clegg et al. [57] 3 Characterization of catalysts and catalyst materials 3.1 Zeolites 3.1.1 Zeolite phase identification As described above, Phase ID is the most basic but powerful aspect of XRD. Zeolites, in particular, utilize this technique given that compositionally most zeolites consist solely of SiO2, Al2O3, and various cations with the primary difference being crystalline structure. Among the most useful databases for zeolite work is that maintained by the International Zeolite Association (IZA) [19]. Today, there are about 250 known structures experimentally characterized out of millions calculated to be feasible [58]. Impurities in zeolite XRD patterns are often other zeolite phases due to the kinetic nature of zeolite synthesis – e.g. MFI in MOR [59], MFI in YFI zeolite [60], or LTA in FAU [61,62]. Other common possibilities are salt phases such as NH4NO3, remaining templating agents, dense phase silicas or aluminum phosphates formed during synthesis or starting materials such as silica, alumina, clays, or seed crystals. One complicating factor for zeolite phase identification can be intergrowths. Many known intergrowths are categorized by the IZA. When two zeolite structures are closely related, they can form together during a synthesis in the same crystal [63]. Frequently encountered examples include the FAU / EMT structures [64], the MFI / MEL structures [65,66], beta zeolite [67], and the AEI / CHA structures [64,68], all four of which intergrowths occur within the top catalytically utilized zeolite materials. These related structures are considered polymorphs. If a material is composed of continuous crystals which regularly contain more than one polymorph within the same crystal, this is considered an intergrowth material. It can be easy to mistake an intergrowth for a mixture of phases by the XRD pattern, hence until significant work has been performed, TEM is the best way to be certain that an intergrowth has occurred. When viewing the XRD pattern, if all of the peaks of one phase are broader, this is an indication of a mixture but if certain peaks are broad and others are narrow irrelevant of zeolite phase, the material may be an intergrowth. Another way to tell that the material is an intergrowth and not a mixture is that there should be only one morphology present in the material by SEM. These techniques were illustrated clearly for the case of UZM-55 which is an intergrowth of two polymorphs in about an 80/20 mixture under the conditions studied [69,70]. Other non-classically grown zeolites such as UZM-39, a coherently grown composite structure of TUN and IMF zeotypes, can also show these complicated mixture-like patterns [71]. 3.1.2 Zeolite lattice parameter determination Zeolites can be thought of as an aluminosilicate solid solution and therefore changes in the lattice parameter of a zeolite can be correlated with the Si/Al ratio. The isomorphic substitution of aluminum into a silica lattice causes a unit cell expansion because Al-O bonds are longer than Si-O bonds [72]. Therefore, as the Si/Al of the zeolite increases (i.e. less Al present), the lattice parameter should decrease. In principle, a lattice parameter study can be performed for any zeolite structure across the range of Al content accessible synthetically. In reality, lattice parameter is most frequently used for high Al content cubic structures such as FAU and care must be taken to control for other influencing factors such as pore contents [73]. Pore content also impacts unit cell parameters for low Al content zeolites like FER where coke deposition increases the unit cell size [74]. The other common application of lattice parameter in zeolites is to study expansion or contraction of the framework as temperature changes. For example, the LTA zeolite shows either negative or positive expansion as the temperature changes depending on cations charge balancing the framework Al [75]. Most zeolites and isoelectronic AlPO4 compositions show lattice contraction (i.e. negative thermal expansion) as temperature increases [76,77]. To perform lattice parameter determinations, from the experimentally derived pattern, it is necessary to correct the peak position for sample displacement errors. One common method for this is to dope a sample with a peak position standard such as NIST Silicon 646 possessing a certified unit cell dimension. For a cubic material such as the FAU zeotype, all three unit cell lengths are equivalent, therefore any diffraction peak can be chosen for the measurement because the lengths a=b=c for corresponding crystal dimensions h,k,l. Equation 5 can be solved for a, b, or c for the corresponding Lattice Parameter value once the peak hkl are identified and the 2theta values are calculated from the Bragg Equation 1 where λ is the radiation wavelength. When calculating lattice parameter of individual peaks, it is always best to average at least 3 peaks for any dimension. See Fig. 10 for a graphical description of the information needed for the analysis using a FAU zeolite example. Equation 5: Cubic Space Group Equation: d hkl = a h 2 + k 2 + l 2 For lower symmetry materials, the analysis becomes far more complicated. Hexagonal structures require two values whereas monoclinic structures have three values, one for each abc axis. For lower symmetry materials where a≠b≠c and cell angles, α,β,γ may not be 90°, such as a monoclinic or triclinic crystal structure, this equation becomes even more complicated. Ideally peaks are chosen where only one hkl contains a non-zero value. For example, the (001) peak position can be used to determine the lattice parameter of l, the (050) peak to determine the lattice parameter of k, or the (200) peak to determine the lattice parameter of h. However, due to peak overlap and systematic absences (see Section 2.4.1), these peaks may or may not be suitable for individual peak profile analysis. As there are more independent variables in these lower symmetry systems, it is recommended that more peaks are used to get suitable statistics on the unit cell for each dimension, such that it is often preferable to utilize a whole pattern fitting approach in order to determine the lattice parameters. In addition to the aluminosilicate solid solution, other factors that affect lattice parameter determination are cations, water and hydrocarbons in the cage of the zeolite. If you are trying to show differences in any one of these effects, it is vitally important to keep the others constant. Water content can be readily controlled by hydrating the sample to 50 % RH over a saturated Ca(NO3)2 solution prior to running the XRD scan. Care must be taken that the material doesn’t hydrate or dehydrate while awaiting the scan or the completion thereof. Alternatively, an environmental stage can be used to run the sample at an elevated temperature and therefore “dry”. Because the 2θ / d‐space position of the peak will be measured in the lattice parameter method, being able to model the peak accurately is important. Step size should be 0.01º 2θ or lower to result in a repeatable peak shape. One way to determine if the parameters are sufficient for good peak shape is to ensure that step size is small enough that 7 datapoints are collected over the top of the diffraction peaks. This means that above the half height mark of the peak, there should be at least 7 datapoints as shown in Figure S3. 3.2 MOFs and related porous organic/inorganic materials With a high degree of popularity in the academic literature since their emergence in the 1990s, MOFs and related porous materials have been touted as promising ‘state-of-the-art’ alternatives to the more established porous materials such as zeolites and mesoporous silicas [78]. Including related classifications such as COFs [79], ZIFs [80], POPs [81] etc, what these materials all have in common is an organic component to their crystalline structure. From smaller imidazolates to extremely large 2D and 3D polycyclic aromatics with multiple functional groups, these organic components provide an unlimited number of possible framework permutations. From a practical perspective though, there are some general XRD considerations specific to these materials which should be considered. 3.2.1 Unit cell size considerations As a class of crystalline porous materials, the factors listed above for zeolites are also generally applicable to MOFs. One key factor here is that the organic component often leads to a structural building unit (SBU) which is much larger than that of a typical zeolite as is shown in Fig. 11 for the MTN systems [82]. This in turn leads to significantly larger unit cells and much more complex XRD patterns. When selecting scan conditions for such a system, it is important to consider the reciprocal space relationship. Where the crystal exists in real space, a mathematical construct of ‘reciprocal space’ is used to describe the diffraction spots (or cones in the case of a powder sample where it is averaged around the origin in all orientations). Each spot or peak in the diffraction pattern represents a series of lattice planes in real space and is related to the Fourier transform of the real lattice. The resulting reciprocal lattice vectors have a length of 1/dhkl in units of inverse angstroms. Therefore, large complex structures have more closely spaced diffraction peaks typically with more peak overlap. When visualized in the diffraction pattern, as the unit cell of the target material gets larger, the observed 2θ position moves to lower angle (for the same X-ray wavelength source). If a large cell material is suspected from initial screening, it is important to ensure all the low angle reflections are suitably measured. Therefore, it is important to scan from the lowest allowed starting angle of the diffractometer. This can pose some challenges for some instrument setups as the detector is approaching the direct beam. The ability to setup custom scans to very low angle is possible for many commercially available diffractometers but may require custom configuration settings or other instrument changes which may not be considered ‘routine’ analysis in many academic or industrial settings. Care should be taken to understand the limits of a given system and to work within the manufacturer's guidelines to ensure the detector is protected from direct beam exposure; where necessary utilizing either a beam stop or other attenuation options to limit the over-saturation of the detector. In addition to configuration optimization, it may also be worth considering XRD systems with an alternative X-ray tube. While Cu Kα is ubiquitous in the lab, a longer X-ray wavelength such as Co or Fe may be advantageous in this particular case as the same hkl reflection (same d‐spacing in the unit cell) is observed at a higher 2θ angle. This enables a user to scan a more typical 2θ range, where the instrument is optimized for signal/noise quality, while ensuring low angle reflections are captured in the scan. 3.2.2 Desolvation effects MOFs can be produced using a wide variety of synthesis techniques, from simple reflux and related hydrothermal methods to complex solvothermal methods under inert gas conditions. These solvent molecules and other guest species can frequently end up in the pore/channel system of the MOF. Ready exchange in and out can lead to very significant changes to the 3D structure of the MOF material [83,84]. In addition, even with careful preparation, some frameworks are air-sensitive, and/or any removal of the solvent can lead to collapse of the structure. Therefore, sample preparation prior to any analytical technique should be approached with caution to ensure the material itself is not changing or degrading before the analysis is completed. For XRD, it can be advantageous for some MOF materials to analyze the synthesized material in-situ such as by using sealed capillaries under the synthesis solution, i.e. ‘mother-liquor’. After confirming that the material is stable to solvent removal, ambient air and humidity exposure etc. the typical XRD sample preparation and analysis can resume. 3.2.3 Beam damage and transparency While beam damage is a factor which could impact many samples, special care must be taken with MOFs due to the potential for photo-active organic species. MOFs also have a tendency to exhibit a high transparence for typical lab-based Cu Kα X-rays due to their high surface area, low structural density, and typical compositions high in light elements possessing low Mass Adsorption Coefficients (MAC). Transparence of a sample is typically related to the atomic mass of elements within a sample, with heavier elements absorbing more x-rays. While this low sample MAC can help with certain transmission experiments, it can lead to poor data quality in BB geometry experiments, as the beam penetrates deep into the sample. In mild cases this effect leads to peak broadening and peak shifts as significant portions of the measured diffraction come from below the sample surface for which the measurement is aligned. This is observed as a sample displacement error combined with additional peak broadening which makes measurement of crystallite size challenging. In extreme cases where the beam fully penetrates the sample, diffraction from the base of the sample well or sample stage can be observed as a significantly displaced diffraction pattern. In such cases it may be preferable to measure BB geometry using a ‘zero-background’ sample holder where an orientated Si single-crystal wafer is used as plate on which to mount a thin layer of powder sample. 3.2.4 MOF structure solution While single-crystal structure determination is easily the most popular method of MOF structure solution, as described in Section 2.4, not all MOFs can be grown as single crystals. While reciprocal space or ab-initio structure solution methods are commonly used for many materials, given the x-ray absorption differences between elements in the composition of typical MOFs, the Patterson method of ab-initio structure solution can be very successful [85]. The Patterson function is a modification of the electron density function (where electron density is proportional to the amplitude of the structure factor ρ(xyz) ∝ |F(hkl)|) where the structure factors are replaced with the square of the structure factor (P(uvw) ∝ |F(hkl)|2). This modification is useful as the |F(hkl)|2 can be calculated from the diffraction pattern as the scattering intensity is also proportional to |F(hkl)|2. Essentially, a Fourier map of the unit cell is used to generate peaks related to vectors between atomic pairs, where the peak height is also proportional to the atomic numbers involved and therefore well suited to locating heavier atoms. The product of this approach is then a series of vectors between atomic pairs mapped onto the unit cell. Typically, this approach is better suited to small and relatively simple systems with strong reflections because the vector map between the atom pairs rapidly becomes too complex to reliably resolve as the number of unique atoms in the unit cell increases. However, some modern implementations of this technique have been developed and used to solve zeolitic materials [86]. The Patterson method is sometimes referred to as the ‘heavy atom method’ and for materials like MOF structures where the metal centers are heavy elements relative to the organic component, it is an important tool to provide the basis for further model development [87]. The Patterson method can be very useful to determine changes at a metal cluster occurring during a catalytic reaction even if a complete structure model is not yielded. 3.3 Metal oxides XRD is a powerful tool in the analysis of metal oxide phases as changes in stoichiometry and oxidation state can be observed as different structural forms of the metal oxide which can be identified and quantified by XRD analysis. Phase identification and peak position can be used to identify the primary phases with peak broadening used to understand the microstructure where grain size and/or strain properties are important. Variable temperature in-situ studies can provide valuable information on the stability of phases and the conditions required for phase transitions and variable gas environments can be used to replicate process conditions [88]. Prior to any analysis, the first consideration in this class of materials is the measurement condition. Metals and metal oxides (particularly those with heavier elements) can pose a challenge for XRD analysis due to absorption effects and in some cases fluorescence. For example, iron containing samples fluoresce highly when exposed to Cu radiation, contributing to high pattern background. This can be remedied by changing x-ray source element (for iron samples, the classical choice would be cobalt x-rays) or through the use of more sophisticated beam optics and/or energy dispersive detectors as described in Section 1. X-ray absorption effects can limit the ability to perform certain transmission experiments on a laboratory X-ray source. For example, a typical 0.7–1 mm capillary full of pure metal oxide (iron oxide, tungsten oxide, etc.) can have 0 % transmission for a CuKα beam. In typical BB geometries (Fig. 3B), long counting time is quite often necessary for good statistics due to low signal intensity. If considering a transmission experiment, it is useful to first estimate the expected transmission. Some calculators are available online where transmission factors in the 25–75 % range are preferable [89]. Another factor to consider is that not all metal oxides, particularly in supported catalyst systems, are crystalline or have large enough crystallite size to be detectable by XRD. Internal standards can be used with Rietveld analysis to estimate the amorphous content of a sample, but as with other systems it is always beneficial to combine the XRD analysis with other characterization methods to validate the results. Lastly, as a general note, due to the lack of porosity and short d‐space distances in metal oxides it is often preferable to measure not at low angle, but up to relatively high 2θ angles approaching 120º instead. 3.3.1 Alumina – Al2O3 Aluminas are one of the most important classes of materials for industrial catalytic supports particularly in the refining and petrochemicals space [90]. Thankfully, they do not strongly absorb x-rays. From the porous and poorly crystalline γ-alumina to the extremely hard and highly crystalline α-alumina with a range of tunable properties in between, alumina materials are widely utilized as cheap and effective supports and/or co-catalysts for a broad range of applications. The range of starting aluminum hydroxide phases and resulting transition alumina phases is shown in Fig. 12. Despite the value and interest in alumina, there is still debate on the microstructure of some of the most important transition phases. For example, the structure of the bulk γ-alumina phase is generally agreed upon [91], although the subtleties of the morphology, porosity, exposed crystallographic surfaces and vacancies of other phases are of great importance to the catalytic activity and still discussed. These intricacies of its microstructure are still heavily debated for the widely used γ-alumina phase and can vary depending on the preparation method and are tunable with subsequent post-synthetic treatments. While from a crystallographic perspective it can be convenient to think of the γ,δ,θ transition phases from boehmite (Fig. 12 – orange, red, blue) as distortions from a face-centered cubic (f.c.c) spinel-like oxygen lattice with different distributions of octahedral and tetrahedral aluminum on the interstitial sites, the inherent disorder in these systems means that the observed XRD pattern is a mix of features from the more ordered oxygen sublattice (narrower diffraction peaks) with severely broadened and distorted features (broad scattering features) from the disordered aluminum distribution and other faulting/defects present (Figure S4) [92]. Fitting these patterns is also a challenge as the conventional Rietveld method is not appropriate, in this case, as it requires an ordered crystallographic model. The observed XRD pattern for most of the metastable transition phases, while distinguishable for the purposes of phase identification, remain difficult to model in a quantitative whole pattern fitting approach to the XRD (Figure S4). This significantly impacts analysis of multi-component catalysts discussed in Section 3.6. Alpha alumina (α-Al2O3, also known as corundum) is the thermodynamically stable end member of the transition series and also an important reference material used in XRD analysis. Due to its cost effectiveness and well-ordered crystal structure, high purity corundum is commonly used as an XRD intensity standard (NIST SRM 676a) [93,94]. A common application is to monitor the source intensity of an X-ray tube and correct for decay in the source intensity. α-Al2O3 can be prepared as either a milled powder for manual sample preparation or as a fixed ceramic plate available from some vendors with their XRD instrumentation as a more permanent calibration standard. In addition, the elemental composition is similar to that commonly found in many catalysts discussed here (zeolites, silica, aluminas, etc.) and it can be a good choice for a known weight fraction dopant in Rietveld studies to quantify the amount of amorphous material present. The structural disorder in transition alumina phases means that most conventional XRD analysis methods for direct microstructure measurements are not directly applicable such as crystallite size, strain and Rietveld quantification. This is due to the presence of significant Debye scattering arising from the structural disorder which is convoluted with the typical Bragg diffraction from the ordered crystalline domains [95]. For experts, this scattering can be calculated using the Debye scattering equation and has been attempted to develop structural understanding of various alumina phases such as γ-Al2O3 or δ/θ-Al2O3 [96] but is not practical for routine analysis at this time. However, XRD can still provide a lot of useful information on these systems to develop an understanding of how features of the alumina relate to the catalyst performance. In the initial catalyst or support preparation stages, XRD is a valuable tool to ensure either synthesized or commercial purchased material is the correct or expected alumina phase. Aluminas are a case where it is better to consult the published examples of real patterns either in journal articles or books rather than rely on database line patterns as simulated line patterns often do not represent the nuance of the profile shape and broadening observed in the experimental alumina patterns (Figure S4) [97]. XRD can also be used to probe the stability and/or changes of the alumina phase during any preparation, pre-treatment or impregnation steps involved in the catalyst work up or post exposure to operating conditions. Typically, one should compare examples from the same sample before and after as changes may be subtle and difficult to quantify. The combination of alumina with other catalyst materials such as zeolites or metals into technical bodies is discussed in Section 3.6. 3.3.2 Zirconia and other metal oxides Four different ZrO2 phases are known and commonly seen in catalytic applications [98,99]. The monoclinic and tetragonal zirconia phases are often seen near room temperature in many preparations [100] while the high temperature cubic zirconia phase is well studied in automotive catalysis. The relative proportion of cubic, monoclinic and tetragonal phases is well known to have impact in catalysts such as sulfated zirconia [101,102]. The orthorhombic phase is less studied [103,104]. The cubic and tetragonal phases are especially difficult to tell apart by XRD – our recommendation is to utilize detailed high angle scans with monochromated x-rays [105,106]. Another method that can be successfully used is direct derivation (i.e. Toraya’s method, see Section 2.3.2), although we caution, the composition of the sample needs to be well characterized and devoid of amorphous phase(s), a condition not always true of catalyst materials [107,108]. As a first note, when performing Rietveld refinements on zirconias or other metal oxides, particularly those undergoing a phase transition, it is important to ensure that the appropriate structural models are used to adequately fit any structures and structural distortions observed. Specific concepts that should be considered for metal oxides in selecting the appropriate structure for fitting are discussed throughout the remainder of this section. Metal oxides typically have a very small unit cell, therefore atomic positions in the asymmetric unit are often on symmetry operators i.e. ‘special positions’ within the cell which can constrain some distortions leading to a change in the unit cell and space group symmetry. These can be significant changes even with relatively subtle and reversible changes in sample conditions. It is important with in-situ studies or ex-situ following treatments to ensure the data collection range is sufficient to capture multiple diffraction peaks ensuring bulk structural changes are observed rather than closely monitoring a single peak. Several classic solid solutions are encountered in zirconia materials. The first is the replacement of Zr with analogous Hf. The two elements are completely miscible in oxide systems and most zirconia obtained commercially contains a reasonable proportion of Hf. Good linearity, albeit with some negative deviation from Vegard’s law, is observed for lattice parameters in the monoclinic and tetragonal phases, with Zr containing oxides having larger lattice parameters [109]. Vegard’s law states that if two components have the same crystal structure then the lattice parameter of the mixture is approximately the weighted mean of the lattice parameter of the two individual components and while some exceptions exist, it is often a reasonable approximation [110]. The second commonly seen solid solution and among those most important for catalytic purposes are the rare earth doped cubic zirconias (YSZ) [106]. These are often studied by Rietveld analysis due to the need to determine small changes in unit cell size. As one example, the crystal structures of monoclinic, tetragonal, cubic, and rhombohedral (Sc2Zr7O17, ß-phase) solid-solution phases have been refined by using the Rietveld analysis of the XRD data at room temperature of arc-melted ZrO2- X ScO1.5 (X = 0, 2, …, 20, and 22 mol%) samples. The results are interpreted as indicating the monoclinic and tetragonal ZrO2 phases convert to tetragonal and cubic phases, respectively, as Sc doping increases [111]. The utilization of the rare earth dopants Ca, Y, and Ce are well known to stabilize the cubic form of zirconia at lower temperatures relevant to catalysis [112]. The insertion of Zr into CeO2 phases is well known in automotive catalysis, but in analyzing the solid solutions, care must be taken to understand the impact of Zr insertion versus oxidation state changes of ceria. Oxidation state affects the ionic radius of the element, which impacts unit cell sizes. Cerium may exist as Ce4+ (0.97 Å) or Ce3+ (1.14 Å), while Zr is strictly 4+ and has a significantly smaller ionic radius (0.84 Å) [113]. Additionally, commercially relevant automotive catalysts contain not only CeO2/ZrO2, but also Al2O3 as support materials, leading to more complex mixed metal oxides [114]. Analysis of mixed metal oxides is similar to that of the single metal with the added possibility of mixed occupancy sites. For well-studied systems such as spinel, perovskite, etc. used in oxygen evolution or CO oxidation there is a known citing preference for different elements in the system and if sites are all occupied by a single atom type, position and occupancy can be determined using Rietveld analysis thus bulk composition can be determined [115–117]. For more complex systems with disorder or mixed site occupancy, XRD is useful to develop a starting structural model for additional local structure characterization and molecular modeling work to fully understand the local and bulk structure. One example here where XRD plays a significant role in characterization are the methanol synthesis catalysts typically comprising Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 [118], although simpler systems such as Cu/CeO2 have also been well studied [119]. Methanol synthesis catalysts have been studied for many years as Cu and Zn form solid solutions in many oxides [120], ZnO and Al2O3 can react to form zinc aluminates [121], and the copper metal can be oxidized to form CuO or Cu2O like phases on the surface of the catalysts. In complex systems like these, XRD should be coupled with additional techniques to finalize hypotheses of catalytically active sites. Sulfates and phosphates are further examples of metal oxide phases used catalytically [122]. In our work in bio-derived catalytic transformations, these oxidic materials are frequently used [123]. While bulk sulfate or phosphate phases typically have well defined patterns [124], some supported phases like sulfated alumina or stannia show little to no difference from the alumina or zirconia support by XRD even as catalytic properties change significantly [125,126]. Other phases have very ill-defined x-ray diffraction patterns from which it is difficult to determine much information [127]. Again, analytical caution must be taken with these materials as amorphous surface layers not readily visible by XRD can form [128], and water can cause surface hydrolysis [129], so XRD analysis should be coupled with other techniques such as FT-IR and/or Raman [130]. 3.4 Metal sulfides Bulk sulfide phases can be readily distinguished from each other and XRD is very useful for bulk phase determination; in particular we point the reader to Holder and Schaak’s tutorial on powder XRD for nanoscale materials, all of the examples of which concern sulfides [131,132]. In catalysis, sulfide phases are used extensively in reactions including hydroprocessing, photocatalysis [133], and water splitting where molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) phases are some of the most used in catalysis. Additionally, the catalyst active sites in these materials are often formed by insertion of other metals onto Mo sites, or by local disruption of the bulk structure determined by XRD and sulfides are sensitive to oxidation, so care should be taken while analyzing most sulfides. Synthetically, these materials are typically prepared by sulfidation of oxide precursors using in-situ H2S or dimethyldisulfide treatments. While not perfect, it is therefore often easier to analyze the oxide precursor material rather than the sulfide catalyst material [134,135]. Due to the broad patterns, plethora of sulfide deficient phases, difficulty of in-situ or controlled atmosphere XRD, and the small structural impacts of cobalt and/or nickel promotion at MoS2 crystallite edges, x-ray diffraction is often not the most definitive technique for characterization of slight differences amongst catalytically active materials [136]. SEM/STEM, UV–VIS, IR, Mössbauer, EXAFS and new techniques such as Modulation Excitation spectroscopy all tend to provide greater information regarding the active species within / at the edges of the large sulfide sheets [137–139]. Quite frequently, only small differences exist in the diffraction patterns between fresh and used catalysts [140].
