As will be discussed in greater detail in Section 3.6, when sulfides are used in combination with zeolites, XRD is useful to determine the crystallinity of the zeolite, though we caution that the mass absorbance coefficient (MAC) must be accounted for as previously described in Section 2 [141]. 3.5 Metals Metals can be dispersed in a catalyst for various performance effects. Typically, those of us in catalysis are analyzing not the bulk metal, but metal clusters supported on an oxide or other support, therefore please also see Section 3.6 for greater details on analysis. If the metal clusters are small and/or at a low enough loading level, it is likely that XRD will not detect them. Typical detection levels are in the 1–2.5 nm metal agglomerate size, depending on metal, support, and equipment [142]. However, even at very low loading level such as 0.25 wt%, if the metal clusters become large enough, it is often possible to detect these “agglomerated” metals. The ability to track metal agglomeration in a catalyst can be a valuable performance variable. Detection of a low-level contaminant such as this with a high x-ray absorbance coefficient requires a long scan across the largest peak which does not interfere with other peaks related to the material. An example of this would be scanning from 45 to 48º 2θ for 1.5 h or longer to look for the main peak of platinum (111) in a catalyst because agglomeration is suspected. The time listed here assumes a standard lab instrument using a Cu source and will depend on detector sensitivity and x-ray intensity. The ASTM (American Society for Testing and Materials, an international standardization organization) method using XRD should be used for this application [143]. The same scan should be run on a comparative catalyst (same general make-up) known to have no agglomeration. Then these patterns can be overlaid and compared. New techniques for analysis of metals by XRD are always being investigated, key is the ability to discern effects like surface oxidation and the impact on the data analysis [144]. The International Center for Diffraction Data (ICDD) contains powder diffraction file card data for all individual metals. Care must also be taken when identifying platinum (ICDD#4-0802) and palladium (ICDD#46-1043) because their most intense peaks are less than 0.5º 2θ apart. Typically, this most intense peak is the only diffraction peak present in Pt or Pd supported catalysts at industrially relevant levels. While rarer, the solid solution of Pt/Pd is used in some catalyst formulations. Unless the identity is known by another method or an internal standard is used in the XRD analysis, elemental analysis should be used as confirmation. Additionally, use of a chemisorption method such as H2/O2 may be a better method to fully characterize Pt catalysts [145,146]. Metallurgy is a large field largely beyond the scope of this review but is an important part of catalysis because reactor vessels are usually various steel compositions. When performing phase ID on metal mixtures, metal oxides and/or metal sulfides it is important to watch for metal-metal substitutions because when these substitutions occur the patterns can be indistinguishable with standard techniques. For example, the various compositions of steel tend to have very similar patterns thus a Fe/Cr/Ni and Fe/Cr/Cu unless run side by side will be very difficult to distinguish by XRD alone. Metals from reactor walls can infiltrate into the catalyst. In the same way Fe3O4 (Magnetite) ICDD#19-0629, is very similar to ZnFe3O4 (Franklinite) ICDD#22-1012. In cases like these, it is critical to have elemental analysis along with XRD to be able to definitively identify the phase(s) and levels of various metals present. 3.6 Catalyst formulations containing more than one type of material While the prior sections have focused on pure catalyst materials, technical bodies of >1 mm are actually used in commercial catalytic applications for reasons including ease of loading and unloading, pressure drop across reactor bed(s), and mechanical stability during all phases of operation including startup and any necessary regenerations. Technical bodies are catalyst formulations existing in a shape that works well for the reaction engineering of the catalytic reactor. Common production techniques for these bodies are extrusion, marumerization, and spray drying. Most materials do not hold together into a stable technical body, so these technical bodies are often complicated multi-component formulations comprising more than one of the types of material discussed above. We point readers to several excellent works on the impact of binding and forming a catalyst material into a technical body and focus on how to use combinations of the techniques described above to characterize these difficult materials [147–149]. Because these technical bodies contain multiple materials, one must always consider that XRD is a technique leading to a diffraction pattern corresponding to the linear combination of phases as described in Section 2.3.1. Hence, for a catalyst that has, for example, 75 % zeolite and 25 % alumina, the XRD pattern will approximate 75 % of the zeolite pattern plus 25 % of the alumina pattern added together. However, the dominant peaks in an observed pattern are those of materials with high crystallinity, so that highly crystalline materials (e.g. quartz) can have very prominent diffraction peaks in an observed pattern even at low concentration. Additionally, mass adsorption effects need to be accounted for during quantification studies. Therefore, x-ray absorption correction, relative intensity versus starting materials, and mixture studies are often needed to perform any level of quantitation in technical bodies. Transition alumina-based catalysts can take many forms but the most relevant classification here from an XRD analysis perspective is the crystalline state of the catalyst or active species which is combined with the alumina. At one end of the scale is a high percentage crystalline material such as a zeolite with a transition alumina binder, the other end is a highly dispersed or amorphous metallic phase impregnated into or coated on an alumina or mixed metal oxide support such as an automotive three-way catalyst (Rh/ZrO2-CeO2/Al2O3) [150,151]. If the crystalline phase of interest (a zeolite for example) is the majority phase in a mixture with γ-Al2O3, it is possible that this main phase can be analyzed directly by conventional XRD methods essentially ignoring or excluding the presence of the poorly crystalline alumina as a background level phase (Figure S5). It is important to note that there may be some limitations in regions where the more ordered diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 are more intense and can interfere with the primary phase however peak intensity and crystallite size analyses on select well resolved diffraction peaks can be performed reproducibly to monitor the condition of these catalysts. It is also possible to perform analyses, such as lattice parameter of the crystalline phase, which can be used to directly probe catalytically important information (e.g. zeolite framework Si/Al ratio) difficult to probe with other techniques. As the quantity of crystalline material in the mixture drops, the ability to resolve and fit individual peaks becomes more challenging and typically requires the XRD measurement time to be increased appropriately to improve the signal to noise ratio (S/N) of the measured peak. As the measurement noise is proportional to the square root of the signal count, it may be necessary to have significantly longer measurement times to noticeably improve S/N. For this reason, it may be advantageous where instrument time is limited to first survey scan the material with a quick full range scan and select a specific region of the diffraction pattern to focus on for a much slower scan for any detailed peak fitting analyses. It is worth noting that while this may be possible with the poorly crystalline γ-Al2O3, as the crystalline order of the transition alumina increases such as in θ-Al2O3, it becomes much more difficult to ignore its presence and find suitably resolved and isolated peaks of the target phase, however, qualitative comparisons and phase identification approaches are still valuable even if it is much more challenging to quantify those observations. We teach these concepts through an example we published where a MTW zeolite catalyst was phosphorus doped to improve oligomerization performance [152]. The initial starting catalyst material was a 75 % MTW zeolite, 25 % gamma alumina extruded body and shown in black in Fig. 13. Already there are two phases contributing to the diffraction pattern, so while the pattern in the region shown appears to be almost entirely MTW zeolite, there is a raised baseline versus the starting MTW zeolite material at locations where gamma alumina has diffraction intensity [152]. Mixture studies of the pure materials (here zeolite and boehmite converted to gamma alumina at the same conditions as the calcination of the technical body) can be used to determine the percentage of zeolite in the formed technical body. As described in previous sections, the catalyst and the reference should be run close in time to each other or normalized to counts of an instrument reference to avoid tube decay effects over time. Then, two different phosphorus treatments were applied which had differing impacts on the catalyst composition and therefore XRD pattern. When NH4H2PO4 was the P source (green, Fig. 13) amorphous AlPO4 was formed from the Al2O3 binder which is not particularly visible by XRD. A small amount of crystalline tridymite AlPO4 was also formed. When H3PO4 was used as the P source instead, significant crystalline AlPO4 was formed as seen in the XRD in blue. Note that one peak of tridymite AlPO4 at 21.6º 2θ is visible as a separate peak, but the second major peak at 20.3º 2θ forms a shoulder on the MTW zeolite peak as it adds diffraction intensity, filling a gap between MTW zeolite peaks. In this way, XRD analysis of technical catalysts may require more effort for quantitative analysis but can still be used to identify phases in a catalyst formulation. Keep in mind that many technical bodies can also include impurities related to the binding agents such as clays or quartz. For natural materials like many clays, these materials may also have significant variation in XRD pattern from batch to batch that impact ability to perform analyses more complicated than Phase Identification. An example is shown in Figure S6, where a catalyst containing FAU zeolite and bentonite clay was analyzed. It contains the expected FAU zeolite, but also numerous peaks from one or more clays. Shown for comparison is the starting clay used to prepare the catalyst. XRD analysis of metals, metal oxides and metal complexes on alumina can also be used to quickly screen the pretreatment conditions and operating status of a catalyst. As with other analyses, it is strongly recommended to use additional techniques to build up an understanding of the system. However, in-situ or ex-situ analyses can be a valuable tool for monitoring phase stability and transitions. Typically, the XRD analysis is used for phase identification purposes as the extent of overlap is often such that detailed microstructure analysis is not possible however it may be possible to resolve select peaks of a target phase for intensity measurements to track a phase change or transition. A good example of this is Ni/γ-Al2O3 where the Ni can be present as dispersed Ni metal (often undetectable) on γ-Al2O3, crystalline Ni metal, NiO or NiAl2O4 (a spinel-like phase with structural similarities to γ-Al2O3) [153]. Monitoring changes in these phases can give insight into the extent of Ni oxidation/reduction or reaction with the alumina to form a nickel aluminate phase. Another productive use of XRD on a supported catalyst is in failure analysis such as when the active metallic species is intercalated into the structure of the alumina itself. This is particularly plausible when the two end members for example Ni/γ-Al2O3 and NiAl2O4 have similar spinel-like structure. Rather than appearing like a physical mixture of two phases, a solid-solution may be formed with a lattice parameter intermediate between that of the γ-Al2O3 and NiAl2O4 if they are assumed to be the same unit cell and symmetry. With careful monitoring of the peak position, hopefully using an internal peak position standard such as Si powder (NIST SRM 640), lattice parameter studies can be used to evaluate subtle peak displacement which would indicate metal intercalation has occurred and could represent irreversible degradation in performance with no change in the bulk catalyst elemental composition. While the above examples here focus on the poorly crystalline γ-Al2O3, it is worth noting that similar approaches are possible with most other oxide supporting phases. As a last example, hydrotreating catalysts for removal of S and/or N from feedstocks are well studied; these often contain a zeolite phase, a sulfide phase, and one or more oxide phases, all of which may contribute to portions of the catalytic activity [154]. In materials like these where sulfide phases are combined with alumina phases, the alumina phases tend to dominate the XRD pattern [155]. Zeolites tend to provide stronger peak intensity, but can be swamped by the x-ray adsorption of metal sulfides or heavier oxides like zirconia. Sometimes carbon is visible in spent catalyst samples, but far more frequently no evidence for even graphite (one of the most crystalline carbon phases) is found [156]. XRD is a very useful technique to understand changes in catalyst structure as a function of activation and time on stream, but relatively detailed methods need to be developed for each type of multi-material catalyst formulation. 4 Conclusions and final thoughts X-ray diffraction is a powerful, largely non-destructive, structural characterization technique which with modern equipment can also be quick and easy to perform. Through this review we focus on the practical aspects of XRD from the perspective of a beginner to intermediate level user of the technique. Modern instrumentation and diffractometer equipment is now more automated and accessible to the end users with basic training on the sample preparation and software interface. This ease of use can unfortunately also mean that data are collected, measured, and reported with minimal, or sometimes improper interpretation. Within this tutorial we break down the typical information which can be obtained from powder XRD and provide some examples and tips on where and how it can be useful when applied to common catalytic systems. Particularly in the field of catalysis, all characterization techniques only provide part of the picture with regards to the complete working of an active material. XRD analysis can provide valuable information on the bulk structure(s), the microstructural properties and stability or behaviour. As a bulk technique it is not sensitive to the more subtle surface effects. While XRD analysis can provide some vital structural input and key performance markers when properly interpreted, it should be used in conjunction with other analytical techniques. Techniques such as IR, NMR, XPS, electron microscopy, molecular modelling etc. can be used together with the structural analysis from XRD studies to develop a more complete understanding of a catalyst system. High-speed detectors and computational improvements have been a step change advancement in the X-ray diffractometer. Looking forward, it is likely that these improvements continue to progress towards faster, smaller, and more efficient systems. This should enable more options for in-situ and operando application for X-ray diffraction analysis which although possible with current capabilities is better suited to state-of-the-art synchrotron facilities with high intensity sources. coredata.dc:description: Despite its importance and ubiquity, the information contained in powder XRD data for materials in catalysts is often neither fully harnessed nor correctly interpreted. In this Tutorial Review, we aim to provide the wider catalysis community with a brief tutorial on some of the most encountered key aspects of powder XRD instrumentation, sample preparation, data collection, and analysis procedures used to characterize both catalyst active phases and the complex technical bodies used in full-scale commercial reactors. We will emphasize characterization of broad classes of materials including zeolites, MOFs, metal oxides, and metals as well as the technical bodies relevant to large scale catalysis where various crystal sizes, shapes, dimensionalities and mixtures of materials are encountered. We hope that researchers across many fields, including those who are new to powder XRD or for whom XRD is not their primary technique, can become familiar with key diagnostics and therefore be better equipped to interpret them in the context of their samples.
